title: Deliveroo sets up gig economy's first rider advisory panel
text:
The company selected the panel members from 130 applicants who raised concerns such as the need for bike repairs, street lighting at night and a reporting system for riders who witnessed accidents.

Panel member Sheeraz Mohd, who rides in Perth while completing a PhD in cancer research, said he realised safety was important after a friend injured himself when his scooter slid in the rain while he was delivering food.

"I think that it's because people are trying to deliver the food quickly," he said.

"Deliveroo never ask you to do it quickly ... but because people want to make more money, they want to deliver more food, they say let's do it quickly."

A Transport Workers Union survey of 160 riders found 46.5 per cent reported they or someone they knew had been injured while working as a food delivery rider.

A Deliveroo rider told the union they "get hit nearly once a week", while an UberEats rider reported "getting doored twice by cars".

In 2016, SafeWork NSW received a complaint that Deliveroo riders were riding without lights at night in the Sydney CBD and "regularly running red lights".

A company spokesman said it had met with SafeWork, which was satisfied with its training and on-boarding approach.

Advertisement

The TWU has argued the new panel was a "smokescreen" and claimed workers who had spoken out about safety concerns had been left off the panel.

The union alleged that Deliveroo last year doubled the distance for riders' delivery orders, which meant people were taking more time to work for the same pay.

The company later introduced a distance fee component, but the union argued pay was still down by 20 per cent.

"The result of these attacks on riders’ take-home pay is to heap extra pressure on riders to make more deliveries as quickly as possible, forcing them to take safety risks," TWU national secretary Michael Kaine said.

"Safety is inextricably linked to pay, as decades of studies on the road transport industry have shown, and delivery riders in the gig economy are no different."

Mr Mohd disagreed that pay was a cause of accidents and pointed out Deliveroo paid extra for surge periods.

"There is no need to rush because you are getting paid decent money," he said.

He said the safety panel wanted to concentrate on educating riders about how to act more safely and suggested rider panels could also be formed for other issues. "It's just the start," he said.
description: Deliveroo has established the first rider-led safety panel for food delivery platforms following reports of cyclists getting 'doored', running red lights and slipping in wet weather.
